explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required for assessing MISRA 'for loop shall be well-formed' for OS_SocketOpen:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER: Macro used at function start. Its expansion/implementation could contain control flow (including for loops) or side-effects that affect whether any surrounding loop in this function would be well-formed.

- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew: Direct callee. If OS_SocketOpen contained a for loop that called this function (or if this function is part of behavior of a loop body), its implementation must be checked for loop counters/side-effects and any for loops inside it.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to obtain the stream pointer. Macro expansions can contain expressions or control structures (including loops) that must be inspected to ensure they conform to the for-loop rules and do not modify loop counters used in enclosing for statements.

- OS_stream_table: Object accessed via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its type/definition may influence macro expansion or indexing expressions that could include loops or modify objects used as loop counters.

- OS_stream_internal_record_t: Type of 'stream' written by memset and fields assigned. Its definition is needed to know whether assignments (e.g. stream->socket_domain) affect any object that could be a loop counter used in a for loop in this function or called functions.

- OS_object_token_t: Type of 'token' passed to other routines and macros. Its representation (e.g. if it is a struct with overloaded operators/macros) could affect whether operations modify loop counters or have side-effects relevant to MISRA checks.

- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: Constant/macro passed to OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew; its semantics could affect which code path is taken inside that routine (and hence which loops are executed) and must be known to find any for loops executed as part of allocation.

- OS_SUCCESS: Return constant compared against return_code; needed to determine control-flow (which callees are invoked on success/failure) so all potentially executed code paths and loops are analyzed.

- memset: Standard library call used to initialize the record. If this were executed inside a for loop body, its behavior would be part of the loop body semantics; include to confirm it has no persistent side-effects that violate clause 2/3 (usually safe but include for completeness).

- OS_SocketOpen_Impl: Direct OS-specific implementation called from this function. Its body must be inspected because the MISRA rule requires analysing the behaviour of any functions called within a for-loop body. Even if OS_SocketOpen has no for loop, any loops inside OS_SocketOpen_Impl (or those it calls) are relevant if they are conceptually part of the same operation.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew: Direct callee after OS_SocketOpen_Impl; its implementation may contain for loops or modify objects that would interact with loop counters or flags in enclosing loops and thus must be checked.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Shown in the call graph as used by OS_SocketOpen_Impl. Include because it's in the call chain; if OS_SocketOpen_Impl contains for loops or is called within a for loop context, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken's implementation must be inspected for loop-related violations.

- OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl: Also called by OS_SocketOpen_Impl (per call graph). Include to cover deeper callee chains that may contain for loops or modify objects involved in loop control.

- OS_printf: Present in the call graph and commonly used by macros/validation code (e.g. in OS_CHECK_POINTER). Its implementation or use inside macros could produce side-effects; include to ensure no persistent side-effects violate clause 2 when used in loop conditions or bodies.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These unit-test/stub helper symbols appear in the static call graph as possible instrumentation callees. If the build under analysis includes stubs (they may be invoked via macros in the function or its callees), their implementations could contain loops or side-effects relevant to a MISRA for-loop analysis. Include them so the analyzer can decide whether test-hook code affects loop well-formedness.

Notes: The MISRA for-loop rule requires inspecting (a) any for loops in this function and (b) the behaviour of functions called from within any for-loop body. Although OS_SocketOpen itself contains no for statement, full assurance requires the called functions and any macros they expand to (and objects/types passed to them) be available to the next agent so it can locate and inspect any for loops and verify the three clauses, loop-counter usage and side-effects.
